ygData.messageBody:
then we agree to disagree. I'm happy with my higher prices and lower time, you're happy with
your lower prices and higher time. As long as it works for you, it really doesn't matter.
Price fixing is a majority based concept, as long as most of us do it, it's good :) Best of
luck to you and your smithing, and may our market last a long time before the crash :)
-Rennin of E'Ci
Trade Council GM

Peter Wong wrote:

> From: Peter Wong <lkworthpete@...>
>
> Nick Emmerich <seorin@...> wrote:
> From: Nick Emmerich <seorin@...>
>
> "I've worked my models on the assumption that there are a limited amount of
> smiths out there.."
>
> -This "number of smiths" cannot be quantified because more people decide to
> become smiths everday.
>
> "This isn't a matter of competition, it's a matter of 'they want it if they
> can get a fair price'."
>
> -Each smith individually has to determine what is a fair price as you hear
> over and over again depending on their cost, their competition's pricining,
> personality of the individual they are dealing with etc.
>
> "if you want to make a few enemies, go ahead and undersell every smith you
> see. All you'll get is a crashing market on your head and a poisoned dagger in
> your back."
>
> - I hope you're not implying that we cannot determine our own pricing on the
> items we worked hard on to make for fear of making "enemies."
>
> "Back to the point, though, your argument with me so far has been that price
> fixing won't work
> because people will always sell for lower and customers will refuse to buy for
> the higher
> price. The truth is, people are starting to sell for higher all across the
> boards, and
> customers are buying at a greater profit to those of us who have decided to
> price raise."
>
> - Again read up on how price affects a supply and demand model. The reason
> people pay higher prices is not because the price is higher. It's because the
> demand is higher in comparison to the supply. As more smiths enter our
> markets the supply will be higher. Either way this market is going to crash.
> It won't be due to people undercutting themselves. It's called planned
> obsolesence. If you don't know what that means, it's what other people have
> talked about recently. We are making products that once our supply has met
> the demand of the market we have have nothing but a bunch of worthless metal
> in our inventory, because there is no need to replace or repair the item.
> With that in mind who wants to play musical chairs with their inventory and
> pricing? In truth I have never sold an item more than 10% less than what the
> "going price" is, but my point the whole time has been that I will not enter
> into an agreement with people to set my prices. I will sell my product on
> what I deem to be a fair price.
> Likewise if I feel prices are getting artificially high I won't increase my
> prices for them. I don't work in a nursing home. I graduated with a degree
> in accounting from one of the 10 best universities for accounting in the
> country and am now working as a stock trader. I will sell at the prices the
> market demands as long as I'm happy with my profits. You can sell at yours
> and hope the market doesn't disappear on you.
>
> Cerran
